title: 104_s1206
content: The "Adoption Assistance Act" is cited as the short title. It introduces a refundable credit for adoption expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Adoption Assistance Act allows for a tax credit against qualified adoption expenses paid by an individual, with a limit of $5,000. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's income, and no double benefit is allowed. The Adoption Assistance Act limits the tax credit for qualified adoption expenses, excluding expenses covered by other provisions or grants. Qualified adoption expenses include fees directly related to legal adoption, not violating any laws. The term 'qualified adoption expenses' excludes expenses for adopting a spouse's child. Married couples must file joint returns. Amendments are made to related sections in the Internal Revenue Code. Title II of the document focuses on Adoption Assistance for Federal Employees, specifically addressing reimbursement for adoption expenses. The effective date for the amendments mentioned is for taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. Title II of the document discusses Adoption Assistance for Federal Employees, focusing on reimbursement for adoption expenses. The section defines terms like 'agency' and 'adoption expenses' related to the adoption of a child. The document discusses reimbursement for adoption expenses for federal employees, including obstetrical care for the biological mother, medical care for the child, physical examinations for the adopting parent, foster-care charges, and transportation expenses. The head of each agency must establish a program for employee reimbursement, which can only be provided after the adoption becomes final, the child is under 18 years of age and unmarried, and the appropriate application is filed. The document outlines reimbursement guidelines for adoption expenses for federal employees, specifying that benefits are payable if other programs do not cover the full amount, with a maximum limit of $2,000 per parent. If both parents are eligible, each can receive reimbursement, but the total amount cannot exceed $4,000. Guidelines for implementation and interagency cooperation are also included. The document outlines reimbursement guidelines for adoption expenses for federal employees, specifying that benefits are payable from the appropriation or fund used to pay the employee. An application for reimbursement may not be denied based on marital status. The Office of Personnel Management may issue guidelines for uniform administration, and agencies must follow these guidelines. The Office may provide assistance to agencies upon request to implement this section. Title III of the document excludes adoption assistance and specifies that benefits are applicable to postal employees as well. The effective date for this title is October 1, 1995, and applies to adoptions finalized on or after that date. Title III of the document excludes adoption assistance and specifies benefits for postal employees. The effective date for this title is October 1, 1995, and applies to adoptions finalized on or after that date. Employee gross income excludes adoption assistance benefits, including military adoption assistance benefits, for adopting a child. Definitions include employer payment of adoption expenses and military benefits under specific codes. The term 'qualified adoption expenses' includes fees, court costs, attorney fees, and other necessary expenses directly related to legal adoption of an eligible child. An 'eligible child' is defined as an individual under 18 at the time of adoption or who is physically or mentally incapable of self-care. Coordination with other tax provisions will be regulated by the Secretary. The text chunk discusses the amendment of the table of sections for part III of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code related to qualified adoption expenses. The amendments made to sections 137 and 138 relate to adoption assistance and cross references to other Acts. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
